140 The Jeake Family of Rye, 1640-1736 The well-dressed man about town, 1681

[110] James Wightman to Samuel Jeake junior, 12 February 1681. Original letter. ESRO FRE 4992

London 12" Feb: 1680/1 Loving Cousin Yours I received this day and understand you would have a fashionable watch, that which I would advise you to is a pendulum watch as wee call them, which is with a spring under the balanc which regulats the worke soe that it goes better then one with a balance onely as for the studed caces they are still in fashon onely some allteration in the order of them the price of such a watch will be £7: but if you fix upon such a one as Mr Smiths it was a shillin or two under five pounds and ten shilling, pray be pleased to send which you pleas to have and I shall take extraordinary care in making it, this with our respects to your selfe and second with our sarvis to my uncle I rest Your loving Cosin James Wightman

To Mr Samuel Jeake Junior in Rye Sussex

[111] James Wightman to Samuel Jeake junior, 19 February 1681. Original letter. ESRO FRE 4993

London Feb 19" 1680/1 Loving Cousin Yours I received and acording to youer desire have sent the bonds and the Ring by Moone the carrier and hope they will come safe to hand, the Ring was three peny wait seven grains, the watch I shall be very carefull in the doing of it and shall be as speedy as I can this with our sarvis to youer selfe and your Lady and allsoe to my uncle I remaine Your loving Cosin James Wightman

To Mr Samuel Jeake Junior in Rye Sussex
